Posts.Content: Hello Weemaw This does sound like an ovarian cyst. Years ago I had the same kind of pain twice and my gynae diagnosed a cyst. He advised taking it out. This was before I went on Tamoxifen but this drug does apparently cause such cysts. Don’t put it with the pain. Speak to your gynae about  it. Good luck F
Posts.Title: Tamoxifen and ovarian cysts

Posts.Content: Hi everyone I’m currently halfway through 20 sessions of RT. I’ve also been on Tamoxifen for about five weeks. I had a bad reaction to the Wockhardt brand with terrible pelvic pain, but my GP prescribed Buscopan which is a muscle relaxant and that helps a bit. I’ve switched to the Teva brand and that seems to be going better. The only difficulty will be insisting I get this brand in future as so many chemist say they just get what their supplier sends them. I foresee a continuing struggle with this! About R1 and R2 – A’s this is fairly new I printed off details of these and brought them to the radiographers at my measuring up session. They didn’t know about them but were pleased to get the info and so I’ve been able to use them as my GP agreed to prescribe it. You can go onto the site to find the PIP numbers. If you’re having difficulty let me know and I will put them on this thread. They’re certainly helping me, as my breast is very red and painful. I’m just hoping that the skin holds up for the second half of the sessions. Best wishes to everyone for your treatment. F
Posts.Title: ☢☢☢ April 2018 Radiotherapy Club ☢☢☢

Posts.Content: Hi PennyL Glad you can get yours from Morrisons. We don’t have one near me but I’ve found a Pharmacy who is willing to search it out for me. This illness is a perpetual quest isn’t it?  Best wishes F
Posts.Title: ☢☢☢ April 2018 Radiotherapy Club ☢☢☢

Posts.Content: Hello Ronstar I echo Whathappened’s comments. I hope everything turns out really well for you and your daughter.  Best wishes  F
Posts.Title: Walking back to Happiness

Posts.Content: Leolady56 I’m so sorry you had to cancel your holiday. That must have been a massive disappointment for you both. This whole insurance issue is a real headache. I’ve only really got one suggestion. Maybe try going through an insurance broker rather than directly as they know the market better than we do and and can usually negotiate better rates too.  Lim so impressed you tried Indian cookery. That’s  really going to pep up your menus. Do tell us how you get on. I haven’t got out today as it’s been raining all day but you inspire me to try tomorrow.  F
Posts.Title: Walking back to Happiness

Posts.Content: Terrific news that you are out Leolady. Sorry to hear about the SEs. This seems to happen to many of us. Fantastic news about the haircut. No wonder you felt good.  Hope that progress is now only up and positive.  F
Posts.Title: Walking back to Happiness

Posts.Content: Leolady56 I do so agree! Along with others I deliver our Residents Association newsletter - we haven’t yet persuaded residents to use a Facebook page. Some letterboxes chop the fingers as they snap shut, others scrape the hands with the antidrafts brush and yet others are so low that one has to practically lie in the ground to put anything in. The posties have a terrible job.  F
Posts.Title: Walking back to Happiness

Posts.Content: Hello WhatHappened I'm sorry to see that you are struggling. It happens to all of us I’m afraid so we are so sympathetic. I wonder if what you need is a regular call from someone who has gone through a similar experience? The Breast Cancer Care service “Someone like me” does just that. You speak to them and they find a volunteer to match you. If you are interested the no to call is  0808 800 6000 l’ve used this service myself while I was undergoing major treatment and it was so helpful. Very best wishea F
Posts.Title: Walking back to Happiness

Posts.Content: Dear Ronstar So sorry to hear about your car. That’s seriously bad news and such a horrible thing to happen when you are mid treatment. You may not want to go public but I’d be inclined to put a notice on your car saying “Whoever trashed my car should know that I have cancer! Thank you!” What a lovely photo. I’m glad that you got a bit of your day Very best wishes  F
Posts.Title: Walking back to Happiness

Posts.Content: I didn’t have any walks today either because the dishwasher broke down. I then spent time on the phone trying to find a plumber to come and fix it but no joy before the weekend. So my carefully planned set of menus to cheer myself and the family up had to be abandoned because we would’ve spent hours washing up afterwards! The only amusing part of this was my husband’s horror at the idea of any washing up. When we first got married I ordered a dishwasher but when it arrived he asked why we needed it. I explained that it was to give us more time together (carefully glossing over that I personally hated washing up). His rely was that it was an unreasonable expense, so he sent it back again! Now it’s abundantly clear that he can’t do without it. There is some irony in there somewhere. F
Posts.Title: Walking back to Happiness

Posts.Content: I just joined this thread as I was thinking to setting myself a walking challenge. At the moment my main walk is at the hospital for RT. The pressure on parking is so great that I aim to get there at least an hour in advance as one usually has to queue for a space. I then walk to the other side of the hospital for a coffee and then back again to wait for my appointment. That takes 3,000 to 5,000 steps, depending on which coffee place is open. It’s boring but at least I’m getting in some basic exercise, in addition to my morning exercises.  I’m looking forward to the end so I can plan some lovely country walks. In the meantime I’m enjoying your enticing pictures.  F
Posts.Title: Walking back to Happiness

Posts.Content: Amazing phot Mirabo. I’m also impressed you are doing so much walking. I’m not through RT yet so can’t manage anything like that but you’ve given me a goal.  Best wishes  F
Posts.Title: Walking back to Happiness

Posts.Content: Hi Violetsniff I agree with others. This was so selfish. Even if she didn’t know it was yours, it is a shared garden but she certainly wasn’t sharing. I agree one gets more upset than normal at the moment. Does she know you are being treated? I expect you do not want to have a bad relationship with her but I’d consider telling her if not, as well as mentioning that it was your rose, planted to cheer yourself up.  I hope you can find another way to cheer up.  Best wishes F
Posts.Title: Walking back to Happiness

Posts.Content: Hello Eddiboy and Amalie Eddiboy Try wild garlic instead of basil in a pesto or with pasta, softened in butter and Parmesan.  Amalie Loved the idea of nettle and wild garlic soup. I had to hire a gardener to sort out our garden while I recover and he pulled up all the nettles! I can see that you are knowledgable but just thought I’d mention - blanched Nettle Salsa Verde with other green herbs and nettle tea.
Posts.Title: Walking back to Happiness

Posts.Content: Have a lovely break Leolady56  You deserve it.  F
Posts.Title: Walking back to Happiness

Posts.Content: Seaspirit44 So sorry to hear about your problems. It must be so frustrating and lonely. Seems like you are doing some exercise nevertheless so best wishes for a quick recovery. F
Posts.Title: Walking back to Happiness

Posts.Content: You are most welcome Whitby. What an amazing photo! Best of luck for your chemo sessions. Keep walking if only a few steps. It really lifts the mood.  F
Posts.Title: Walking back to Happiness

Posts.Content: Hi WhatHappened I’ve got a cold like yours it seems. The sore throat has translated into a terrible cough and stuffed up nose. I’ve been advised not to go out - it’s C-4, so that wasn’t a difficult choice. With a compromised immune system we need to avoid it degenerating into something worse. Sending sympathy F
Posts.Title: Walking back to Happiness

Posts.Content: Best wishes to everyone for a very happy New Year and only good news in 2019. F
Posts.Title: Walking back to Happiness

Posts.Content: Thank you seaspirit44. I appreciate that particularly after your experience in the changing room. I’m so sorry you had to be treated to such a crass and unfeeling comment. You took it really well. Congratulations on on that and also swimming outside. I wish I could but RT prevents me for the moment. I’ll think of you. I’ve decided to be very upfront about my treatment. I guess you decided not to as the other woman was disabled but I’ve found it  can be a better way to reproach someone rather than saying what they did upset me. Here you can get it off your chest (Ha!) so don’t hesitate if you have other niggles. We are here to support you.  F
Posts.Title: Walking back to Happiness

Posts.Content: You sound as if you had a magical day Violetsniff. What a wonderful experience to find your own private sanctuary. That’s what we all need.  F
Posts.Title: Walking back to Happiness

Posts.Content: Hi WhatHappened its great that you have decided to get walking again. I use an app called WalkActive which gives tips on how to walk better and tracks steps taken. It will then log by day week etc so you can see your progress.  Best of luck F
Posts.Title: Walking back to Happiness

Posts.Content: Leolady56 and Seaspirit44 So pleased to see that you have both made it back into the choir. That is so uplifting. I used to stand in the front but have worked my way round to the back. There I can open and shut my mouth like a goldfish if nothing is coming out. Unfortunately this make some of my choir mates giggle so I have to keep a very serious face.  What are you both singing at the moment?  Best wishes for a continued recovery. F
Posts.Title: Walking back to Happiness

Posts.Content: Hello Happybird I’m so very sorry to see your news. It’s really hard that you are going this this rollercoaster all over again but from the other side. The fact that you have the same team will be really helpful and some of your coping strategies will help both of you.  Treatment is advancing all the time so there is always hope. Do ask your team about trials and options. I know it’s really tough and we all feel for you. Please keep posting so we can support you. I am sending you a warm digital hug.  Very best wishes to you both. F
Posts.Title: Walking back to Happiness

Posts.Content: Hello everyone I’ve been told I will have 15 sessions plus 5 boosters because my tumour was also very near the surface skin and the surgeon only managed to get 0.5mm clearance. It seems pretty common. Thanks for the extra info Optimistic as I don’t yet know the form the boosters will take.
Posts.Title: Radiotherapy boosters?

Posts.Content: Helen Thank you so much for your reply. Your surgeon’s view is most helpful to me. I am so sorry that you have such a hard decision to make yourself. It would be presumptious of me to give a view but I wish you all the best with your recovery, whichever way you go.  Very kind regards
Posts.Title: Narrow margin of clear tissue after a breast cancer lumpectomy.

Posts.Content: Thanks very much Leolady56. You clearly got everything sorted by just being insistent. I’m feeling rather defeated. I haven’t managed to speak to the oncologist direct. She was away for a while and on her return very busy. My BCN was also away, so I finally got a message to her via another  CN and the message came back that the tumour was very close to the surface under the skin, by which I deduced that there wasn’t enough clearance to do another Op. But now I’m thinking that I need to insist on another meeting with the oncologist to get everything clear. I’m feeling very tired and as I said a bit defeated but will gather my strength as you have so encouraged me. Best wishes F Best wishes
Posts.Title: Narrow margin of clear tissue after a breast cancer lumpectomy.

Posts.Content: Thanks so much for your response Bids 24. I think the recommended minimum is 1 mm so they were obviously satisfied with that. I’m just a bit bothered that mine is half that. Forgive me for asking but did you also have some of your lymph nodes removed? I also asked about the risk of lymphoedema and was told that this shouldn’t be a problem as my lymph nodes were clear. I agree I have been doing quite a lot of research online and there seems to be an ongoing debate about the width of the margin and the impact it may have on recurrence. I just want to make sure that any risk of recurrence is minimised as much as possible. Thanks again for your very prompt response and very best wishes for your recovery.
Posts.Title: Narrow margin of clear tissue after a breast cancer lumpectomy.

Posts.Content: Hello everyone  I just need to share my frustration and unhappiness at the treatment I have received from Boots Chemists. My GP ordered R1 and R2 for my radiotherapy treatment over 10 days ago and despite two visits to my local Boots they still hasn’t arrived. After waiting almost an hour today I established with the help of one of the pharmacy assistants that the products are available but the Accounts department at Boots simply hasn’t paid for them and the supplier won’t release them until they get the payment. The pharmacy assistant was wonderful but it took her over an hour to establish what had happened back at the area office. I am just so upset that I could have been treated in this way when I need these products now urgently for radiotherapy that starts next week. I’ve decided to cancel the order from Boots and go to another chemist, whom I saw today and who assured me he could get these products within two days. This just shows you that large organisations just couldn’t care less about their customers.
Posts.Title: Narrow margin of clear tissue after a breast cancer lumpectomy.

Posts.Content: Thanks so much Leolady56 you are brilliant. I am so grateful for your kind and warm message, You are absolutely right. I will find a way round and keep this quote in mind too. I’m so sorry your daughter had an eating disorder. I really hope she has come through it. Thinking of you both.  Warm hugs F
Posts.Title: Narrow margin of clear tissue after a breast cancer lumpectomy.

Posts.Content: It’s brilliant hear such happy news of your daughter Leolady56 and that you able to support each other so positively. Best wishes for her nursing career - hurrah we need more selfless girls like her - and her wedding.  F
Posts.Title: Narrow margin of clear tissue after a breast cancer lumpectomy.

Posts.Content: Many thanks for these tips Chaka Best wishes for your recovery F
Posts.Title: Narrow margin of clear tissue after a breast cancer lumpectomy.

Posts.Content: Thanks very much for the suggestion Leolady56. I intend to write to the area manager about all this. If that doesn’t produce a response then I will follow your suggestion and contact the CEO.  Very best wishes for your treatment  F
Posts.Title: Narrow margin of clear tissue after a breast cancer lumpectomy.

Posts.Content: This is really helpful guidance Knighthy. And excellent questions too. I’m very grateful .   Very best wishes to your mother for a comfortable treatment and recovery. F
Posts.Title: Narrow margin of clear tissue after a breast cancer lumpectomy.

Posts.Content: Hello Pointer Sorry to hear you have joined our ranks but it’s good news that you are only stage 1 with no lymph nodes. This is the best news and very treatable. You will find lots of advice and friendship here both from the forum and from the Macmillan nurses. I suggest that you hop over to Breast Cancer Care forum as well. They have a service called “someone like you”. They pair you with a volunteer who has been through a similar experience to you and can offer help and guidance by phone. I have found it invaluable. Make good use of your breast cancer care nurse too at the hospital.  All the best F
Posts.Title: Diagnosed Today

Posts.Content: I recently had surgery to remove a 4.5 mm grade 2 invasive ductal carcinoma with DCIS. I was told that my margins were clear although a little close at the front (anteriory), so I was initially pleased with the outcome. Yesterday I had a meeting with the radiologist prior to having radiotherapy and was shocked to hear that the front margin was only 0.5 mm. The guidelines appear to be that a margin of at least 1 mm needs to show clear from cancer tissue. I have been told I will be having a booster week of radiotherapy therapy to address this issue but I’m really concerned that I ought be discussing whether to have a re-excision with my surgeon. I can’t speak to her at the moment as she is on holiday and my breast cancer nurse was really unable to help other than to say I should speak to her. Has anybody had a similar experience?
Posts.Title: Narrow margin of clear tissue after a breast cancer lumpectomy.

Posts.Content: Thank you so much for your prompt response Yorkiejan. I’m interested that your surgeon was pushing for a larger clearance. There seems to be quite a difference between regions in the country. Did you also have some lymph nodes removed? Lymphoedema is something I want to avoid, so hope to make sure it doesn’t happen. My nodes were clear. It’s a hard choice between another operation and booster radiation but thanks for your information. That will be very useful when I get to speak to my surgeon. Very best wishes for your ongoing recovery.
Posts.Title: Narrow margin of clear tissue after a breast cancer lumpectomy.

Posts.Content: Hi jowoomot thanks very much for your reply. You sound like you’ve been through a lot. I hope you are now recovering comfortably. I’ve spoken to my breast care nurse but she wasn’t much help. She said I needed to speak to the surgeon so I’ll have to wait until she’s back from holiday. I’m trying to decide whether another op is worse than an extra week of radiotherapy! Ultimately though I just want to minimise the risk of any recurrence so this may just be a case of more rather than less to be on the safe side.
Posts.Title: Narrow margin of clear tissue after a breast cancer lumpectomy.

Posts.Content: Thanks very much for your reply Yorkiejan. That helps me decide what to do. Good luck with your recovery.
Posts.Title: Narrow margin of clear tissue after a breast cancer lumpectomy.

Posts.Content: Thank you very much indeed Bids24. That is really helpful and will be very useful in helping me get to the right decision. Very best wishes for your overall recovery.
Posts.Title: Narrow margin of clear tissue after a breast cancer lumpectomy.

Posts.Content: Hi Chaka I’m on Tamoxifen which is the best one, as I understand it, for dealing with osteoporosis, if you had an oestrogen positive tumour. Letrozole tends to leech more bone my consultant said. But it very much depends on the characteristics of you to match as to what they will recommend for you.  Good luck with your treatment.  F
Posts.Title: Narrow margin of clear tissue after a breast cancer lumpectomy.

Posts.Content: Thanks so much Jacmatholmad Your reply is so helpful. Leolady56 and you have definitely persuaded me to get another meeting with my oncologist. Thanks so much for your support. Happy Easter F
Posts.Title: Narrow margin of clear tissue after a breast cancer lumpectomy.

Posts.Content: Hello Swolish  On the question of hormone tablets I see that you are oestrogen positive. I imagine that is why your oncologist has recommended that you take hormone treatment as these tablets can be oestrogen suppressers, which is one of the ways to avoid a recurrence. It will depend on your make up as to which is recommended. I am on Tamoxifen, as I also have osteoporosis and this leeches less bone than some of the others. I should speak to you oncologist about the options.  It also depends on your make up as to what side-effects you get from the recommended dose. People experience different effects at different intensities, so there isn’t a common thread. It’s a question of trial and error to some extent.  Very best of luck with your treatment. F
Posts.Title: Narrow margin of clear tissue after a breast cancer lumpectomy.

Posts.Content: Just an update to let you all know that the Buscopan muscle relaxant has been really helpful. I’m feeling much better.  But next drama ....had a struggle to get R1 gel and R2 cream for radiotherapy treatment. Finally got them today after going round various pharmacists, just in time as rads start this afternoon. I feel quite stressed out with it all so wish me luck that it goes well.    Best wishes to you all
Posts.Title: Narrow margin of clear tissue after a breast cancer lumpectomy.

Posts.Content: Thanks very much for this advice Chaza. I’ve decided to book everything in my diary to I keep going for the recommended time.  All the best for your treatment F
Posts.Title: Narrow margin of clear tissue after a breast cancer lumpectomy.

Posts.Content: Thanks so much for your help everyone. I went to my GP today and he has given me new prescriptions for Tamoxifen which I took to a chemist who had the  Teva brand. I’ve also got a muscle relaxant to help with the period pain type symptoms. It’s is Buscopan, which contains hyoscine butyl bromide. I’ll let you all know how it works.    Good luck with with your treatments everyone F
Posts.Title: Narrow margin of clear tissue after a breast cancer lumpectomy.

Posts.Content: Hello Morgana 17 I completely agree with what’s been said so far. Do take some paper and make notes as they tell you the results and the recommended treatment. Also ask questions “why this, why not that, how long?” Also ask for your pathology report so that you can sit and absorb this at home more slowly and then you’ve got your BCN for questions if anything doesn’t make sense. The Breast Cancer Care website has a good booklet on how to understand the report. Good luck with the meeting F
Posts.Title: Clinical Oncology

Posts.Content: My surgeon suggested a bra extender which has been really useful. I got Sports bras for after surgery and then maternity bras from M&S ready for my radiology treatment, as you can open them at the front to put on gel and cream. I got them in my usual size but find I need the bra extender for comfort. I’ve also got a couple of soft bras from Sainsbury that are comfortable but I’m waiting until after treatment finishes as my breast is still swollen.  Good luck with your treatment.
Posts.Title: Advice on bras

Posts.Content: Brilliant news. Congratulations. Weird thing to say when we all this have unwelcome disease. It just means I’m so pleased for you.  Best wishes
Posts.Title: well i am now very worried

Posts.Content: Hello Kargus I completely understand your worries.  I am on Tamoxifen and a few days ago starting getting shooting pains in the same region. Pain in this area is listed as one of the possible side effects of Tamoxifen. Maybe it is also a side effect of Letrozole? I also agree with Granny59’s suggestion of an Oestrogen link as a possible cause. My GP is also sending me for a scan! Do stay in touch and let us know how you go on. Thinking of you.
Posts.Title: well i am now very worried

Posts.Content: Hello Tinker I absolutely agree with Sunnyslava. It’s worth trying the cold cap to protect your hair. It makes you feel more like you when you see a familiar image in the mirror and the emotional side is as important as the physical side. I also agree it’s important to ensure it fits properly, so all your hair is protected. I also ensured that when I washed my hair  I finished with a cold water rinse to protect the follicles.  Don’t put yourself through too much though. If you find it very uncomfortable I would find a wig you like as an alternative. A friend of mine liked her wig so much she wore it even after her hair grew back!  Very best of luck for your treatment and warm hugs  F
Posts.Title: Chemo Jitters

Posts.Content: Hi Pat 22 Don’t forget you have Easter in between and staff holidays. That has pushed my radio from 6 to 8 weeks too.  Best wishes  F
Posts.Title: 2nd lumpectomy done
